channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Attendees could be in for thunderstorms, dust and hail at this year's Burning Man
item.description: These weather patterns are typical for this time of year in Nevada's deserts. Eventgoers should keep an eye on the forecast and prepare for hazardous conditions, the National Weather Service said.
item.content:encoded:
These weather patterns are typical for this time of year in Nevada's deserts. Eventgoers should keep an eye on the forecast and prepare for hazardous conditions, the National Weather Service said.

(Image credit: Julie Jammot)
item.dc:creator: Ayana Archie

item.title: Trump seeks to fire Fed governor Lisa Cook
item.description: President Trump says he's firing Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook, after a Trump ally accused Cook of making false statements on a mortgage application. The president's authority to remove a Fed governor may be challenged in court.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump says he's firing Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook, after a Trump ally accused Cook of making false statements on a mortgage application. The president's authority to remove a Fed governor may be challenged in court.

(Image credit: Drew Angerer)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Trump again calls for FCC to revoke ABC and NBC licenses
item.description: President Trump lashed out on social media late Sunday against ABC and NBC, putting the nation's top broadcast regulator once more at the center of his culture wars.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump lashed out on social media late Sunday against ABC and NBC, putting the nation's top broadcast regulator once more at the center of his culture wars.

(Image credit: John McDonnell)
item.dc:creator: David Folkenflik

item.title: Israeli strikes kill 22, including 5 journalists, in a Gaza hospital
item.description: Israeli forces killed 22 people, including five journalists, in two strikes on Gaza's Nasser Hospital, drawing global condemnation and prompting a rare admission of regret from the Israeli government.
item.content:encoded:
Israeli forces killed 22 people, including five journalists, in two strikes on Gaza's Nasser Hospital, drawing global condemnation and prompting a rare admission of regret from the Israeli government.

(Image credit: Abed Rahim Khatib)
item.dc:creator: Anas Baba

item.title: Epstein accuser Virginia Giuffre's memoir will be published months after her death
item.description: Virginia Giuffre was one of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein's most outspoken accusers. Six months after her death, Giuffre's book detailing her life will be published.
item.content:encoded:
Virginia Giuffre was one of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein's most outspoken accusers. Six months after her death, Giuffre's book detailing her life will be published.

(Image credit: Bebeto Matthews)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: Kennedy Center names new director of dance programming, days after former staff firings
item.description: Stephen Nakagawa, a former Washington Ballet dancer, will be the new director of dance programming. The announcement comes five days after the Kennedy Center's previous chief was dismissed.
item.content:encoded: Stephen Nakagawa, a former Washington Ballet dancer, will be the new director of dance programming. The announcement comes five days after the Kennedy Center's previous chief was dismissed.
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Tsioulcas

item.title: Trump says National Guard is at the ready but hedges on Chicago plans
item.description: President Trump signed a series of executive orders doubling down on law enforcement, particularly related to Washington, D.C., but he equivocated on whether he will send troops to Chicago next.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump signed a series of executive orders doubling down on law enforcement, particularly related to Washington, D.C., but he equivocated on whether he will send troops to Chicago next.

(Image credit: Mandel Ngan)
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordo√±ez

item.title: The U.S. confirms its first human case of New World screwworm. What is it?
item.description: U.S. officials confirmed a case of the flesh-eating parasite in a person who traveled from El Salvador. Screwworm typically affects cattle in South America but has spread north in recent years.
item.content:encoded:
U.S. officials confirmed a case of the flesh-eating parasite in a person who traveled from El Salvador. Screwworm typically affects cattle in South America but has spread north in recent years.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Evergrande's delisting in Hong Kong: key facts to know
item.description: At its peak, China Evergrande Group was worth more than $50 billion. But it all came crashing down in 2021. It was massively in debt and unable to complete some existing projects.
item.content:encoded: At its peak, China Evergrande Group was worth more than $50 billion. But it all came crashing down in 2021. It was massively in debt and unable to complete some existing projects.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Dr Pepper will unwind its merger with Keurig after buying Peet's for $18 billion
item.description: Seven years after they merged, the soft drink maker and coffee pod innovator will become separate companies again. CEO Timothy Cofer said separate coffee and beverage businesses would be more nimble.
item.content:encoded:
Seven years after they merged, the soft drink maker and coffee pod innovator will become separate companies again. CEO Timothy Cofer said separate coffee and beverage businesses would be more nimble.

(Image credit: Richard Drew)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
